results.title: Travelling man
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Pioneers of photography”.
Samuel Bourne, a nineteenth century British pioneer was a travelling photographer. His photographic records of exotic places reveal life in India and Kashmir in the 1860’s and 1870’s.

results.title: Colour and the camera
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Pioneers of photography”.
The theory of three colour photography had been known since the beginning of art but early methods were clumsy. Louis Lumiere devised a process in the late 1890’s which was not marketable and it was not until his autochromes became available in 1907 that colour photography was possible for everyone.

results.title: Famous men and fair women
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Pioneers of photography”.
Julia Margaret Cameron was an outstanding photographer of her day. Despite the restrictions of her social position, she became a recognised artist of portrait photography. Many notable individuals such as Charles Darwin and Alfred Lord Tennyson, were included amongst her subjects. The film gives insight into the social and cultural environment and the moral attitudes that affected concepts of beauty. Demonstrations of photographic procedures used during the 1800’s such as the sliding box camera, plates etc., is also shown. Narrated by Brian Coe.

results.title: Sun pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Pioneers of photography”.
Hippolyte Boyard in Paris, Hill and Adamson in Edinburgh, raised photography to the level of art. Extracts of Boyard’s 1840’s record of Paris are shown along with the pictures of Edinburgh created by these pioneer photographers.

results.title: Mirror with a memory
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Pioneers of photography”.
The new art of photography saw the rise of many new inventors and practitioners. The earliest discoveries of Nicephore Niepce and Louis Daguerre are highlighted in this episode in the excellent series on the history of photography. Includes film shot in France of Niepce’s house and the window from which he took the earliest photograph. Narration: Brian Coe and Hugh Burden

results.title: Hush little baby
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Picture Book Parade”.
Family life in 18th century America is pictured with authenticity and charm in this enchanting animated rendition of the traditional folk lullaby. Illustrated and based on the book by Aliki.

results.title: Mike Mulligan and his steam shovel
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Picture Book Parade”.
An iconographic film using the pictures and text of Virginia Lee Burton’s story of the steam shovel that defied obsolescence by becoming the furnace in the Popperville Town Hall. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: The Circus baby
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Picture Book Parade”.
Tells the story of the mother elephant who learns that she should not try to get her baby to act like a human. Iconographic animation. From the book written and illustrated by Maud and Miska Petersham. Suitable for lower primary level.
